qas.question: What term refers to another way in which dialects are distinguished from languages?
Under the linguistic authority criteria, what is a dialect of German along with Bavarian German?
Of what group of languages is Yiddish a member?
Why is Yiddish not a dialect of German?

answers.text: a Yiddish speaker would not consult a German dictionary

qas.question: A less sociolinguistic notion, what is the term for another criterion for distinguishing dialects?
A more sociolinguistic notion, what is the term for another criterion for distinguishing German dictionarys?
Under what authority would two varieties be considered dialects of different languages if they would refer to the same body with questions about their languages?
In which dictionary would a Yiddish speaker look for questions regarding word usage?
Which language is classified by linguists as being in the Lower High German group?

context: Another occasionally used criterion for discriminating dialects from languages is that of <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0><b6_0>linguistic authority<b6_0/><b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, a more sociolinguistic notion. According to this definition, two varieties are considered dialects of the same language if (under at least some circumstances) they would defer to the same authority regarding some questions about their language. For instance, to learn the name of a new invention, or an obscure foreign species of plant, speakers of Bavarian German and <a1_0>East Franconian German<a1_0/> might each consult a German dictionary or ask a German-speaking expert in the subject. By way of contrast, although <b8_0>Yiddish<b8_0/> is classified by linguists as a language in the "<a2_0>Middle High German<a2_0/>" group of languages, <a3_0>a Yiddish speaker would not consult a <b7_0>German dictionary<b7_0/><a3_0/> to determine the word to use in such a case.
